pageContent:
Award
-
winning journalist Hannah 
Nordhaus tells the remarkable story of 
John Miller, one of America’s foremost 
migratory beekeepers, and the myriad 
and mysterious epidemics threatening 
American honeybee populations. In 
luminous, razor
-
sharp prose, Nordhaus 
explores the vital role that honeybees 
play in American agribusiness, the 
maintenance of our food chain, and the 
very future of the nation. With an 
intimate focus and incisive reporting, in 
a book perfect for fans of Eric 
Schlosser’s
Fast Food
 
Nation
, Michael 
Pollan’s
The Botany of Desire
, and John 
McPhee’s
Oranges,
Nordhaus’s stunning 
exposé illuminates one the most critical 
issues facing the world today, offering 
insight, information, and, ultimately, 
hope.

Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens
Climate 
Change
Habitat 
Change
(loss and 
fragmentation)
Management 
Practices
Agrochemicals
Low diversity
 
(or lack of) resources
and nest sites
Stress of transport and poor 
management
by beekeepers
Especially novel pests and 
pathogens
Insecticides
Fungicides
Herbicides
•
Range distribution
•
Phenological 
mismatch
•
Extreme events

Main stressors of Wild bees? Main stressors of 
honey bees
?

By the end of today, you should be able to: 
1
-
Explain the basic biology of many pests and pathogens of honey bees, 
including: 
 
 
-
Mammalian and avian threats
 
 
-
Tracheal mites
 
 
-
American Foulbrood and European Foulbrood
 
 
-
Nosema and Chalkbrood
 
 
-
Small hive beetles and Wax moths
 
 
-
DWV and other viruses
2
-
Understand that some of those parasites/pathogens of honey bees can 
”jump” onto wild bees thus 
MAYBE 
contributing to the decline of some of 
them
Parasites and Diseases 
of honey bees: 
an overview

Apis
 
mellifera 
has 
many
 
enemies !!!!!
Example of the situation in the US with 
Apis
 
mellifera

Honey bees
 
have many enemies! Not all insects 
are as ”popular” as they are. What makes 
A. mellifera 
a likely target for all sorts of 
organisms on this planet?
•
Find a partner or two (If you see someone 
without a partner, ask them to join you!)
•
Be prepared to share with the whole 
classroom
3 min

A. mellifera 
has 
many
 
enemies and the most serious ones are 
accidental introductions by humans
 
as part of the 
international trade. Example of the situation in the US

European 
honey bees
 
suffering from Vespa 
velutina
A recent example from Europe: 
 
accidental introduction 
of 
Vespa 
velutina
 
in Western Europe

An example from Asia: accidental introduction of  
 
Tropilaelaps
 
mites into Afghanistan, Pakistan, etc.
Serious pest of 
Apis
 
mellifera 
in Asia

entomologytoday.org
/2017/04/17/get

to
-
know

-
mites

another

Part 1. Macroscopic yet not too harmful pests

W
oodpe
c
ker
s 
and bee eaters
Badger
Rac
o
on
Skunks
B
ears
Mouse

Other thieves and scavengers:
ants, wasps, bumble bees, etc.
Unguarded honey is stolen...
...so bees must guard vigilantly

Part 2. Macroscopic and 
somewhat
 
harmful pests

Wax Moth
s
Lesser Wax Moth,
Achroia
 
grisella
(less common)
Greater Wax Moth,
Galleria 
mellonella
old and well
-
known pests of 
honey bees

Moth Larva tunnel
 
through comb
•
    
Will invade active hives with weakened defenses
 
•
    
Workers in strong colonies remove wax moth larvae and repair
 
damage 
•
Main issue: beekeepers store large numbers of wax 
combsthat
 
can be 
destroyed by moths
•
Management: Air tight storage of frames, moth balls, light
.

Tracheal 
Mites 
(
Acarapis
 
woodi
)
•
Small Mites that live in the tracheal tubes in thorax
•
Feed on hemolymph 
•
Damage to tracheal tubes (puncture wounds, debris)
•
Weakens hive and lowers ability to get through winter 
(wing muscles are aff
e
cted).
•
Management
–
Menthol pads
–
70
-
80 F required

Small Hive Beetle
(
Aethina
 
tumida
)
•
Larvae burrowing into combs, eating brood, 
honey and pollen. 
•
Whilst feeding the larvae also carry a yeast 
species (
Kodamaea
 
ohmeri
) which contaminates 
the honey causing it to ferment.
•
Heavy infestations cause the hive to become 
‘slimed out’ and may cause the colony to die or 
abscond.

Good Colony management:
•
Hives should be placed on areas of rubble/hard dry soil to 
minimize SHB pupation sites
•
Bottom boards of hives should be kept free of debris that can 
provide a hiding place or breeding area for SHB. 
Treatments
•
Trapping and baiting
 
Management for the s
mall hive beetle
 
 
 
Disposable small hive beetle trap
(can be filled with mineral oil)

Part 3.Macroscopic and 
serious
 
hive pests

Varroa mites 
•
Varroa Destructor 
•
Number 1 pest
•
The mite
’s
 
presence in a hive puts pressure on the 
health of the colony
•
The leading cause of                                  colony 
overwintering                                    mortality 
because
More during Lecture on November 13
Part 4. Microscopic pests

List of the
 
many
 
A. mellifera 
Pathogens :(
•
Pathogen
  
Diversity
•
Prevalence
 
of
 
Multiple
 
Infections
•
Increased
 
Incidence
 
in colonies that do not survive the 
winter
•
No
 
treatment
 
available
 
for
 
any of the viruses
Viruses
 
black queen cell virus (BQCV)
 
acute bee paralysis virus (ABPV)
 
Kashmir bee virus (KBV)
 
Israeli acute paralysis virus (IAPV)
 
deformed wing virus (DWV)
 
sacbrood
 
virus (SBV)
 
chronic bee paralysis virus (CBPV)
 
Lake Sinai viruses (LSV1 and LSV2)
 
Fungi
 
 
 
 
Nosema
 
ceranae
 
 
 
 
Nosema
 
apis
 
 
 
Ascophaera
 
apis
 
 
 
Aspergillus
 
sp.
Protozoa
 
 
Crithidia
 
mellificae
Bacteria
 
Paenibacillus
 
larvae
 
Melissococcus
 
plutonius

•
Trophallaxis and feeding 
of brood allows transmission 
of DWV between bees
•
Varroa mites also transmits 
DWV to the pupa while 
feeding
•
DWV can 
o
cause deformed wings
o
reduce lifespan
o
weaken the colony and 
make it more vulnerable to 
other stressors.
Deformed Wing Virus
 
(DWV)

DWV levels 
(prevalence of 
workers with >10
7
 
copies of virus) over 
time in colonies that 
survived winter 
(green) and colonies 
that did not (red)
DWV and survival
 
over the winter

Paenibacillus
 
larvae
: 
A
 
microscopic,
 
rod
-
shaped 
bacterium (AFB)
•
Spores of the bacteria are passed from hive to hive 
primarily via robbing and drifting bees. 
•
Young larva
e
 
ingest bacterial spores when fed by 
nurse bees
•
Housecleaning bees then try to remove the dead 
mass and become contaminated with now dormant 
bacterial spores. 
American Foulbrood (AFB)

•
The bacteria consume the larva, which dissolves into 
a gooey mass. 
•
Spores last 
eighty
 
years in woodenware and in the 
environment.
•
AFB is the 
most contagious
 
bee 
disease, and
 
is the 
reason most states have apicultural inspectors. 
•
It is a notifiable disease
AFB 
cted

Management of 
AFB
•
Antibiotic for mild cases 
(NOT allowed in Europe).
•
Otherwise: Burn entire 
hive and cover burn pit!
•
In all cases: 
S
terilize all 
beekeeping equipment.

Note that as of 2017 only veterinarians can prescribe 
antibiotics for honey bees (as for all livestock in the US)

Why is it federally mandated to have medical 
professionals involved in the antibiotic treatment 
of honey bees in the US?
•
Find a partner or two (If you see someone 
without a partner, ask them to join you!)
•
Think of plausible reasons
•
Be prepared to share with the whole 
classroom through 
Polleverywhere

Nosema disease
•
Class Microsporidia (Fungi
,
 
not
 
Protozoa)
•
Two species 
of concern
-
 
Nosema ceranae
 
and N. 
apis
•
Has been a very common disease condition, 50 
-
 
90% of 
the colonies in the US have bees infected with 
Nosema
Nosema spores A: 
N. ceranae
, B: 
N. apis

N
.
 
C
erana
e 
is the most 
detrimental one
•
Ingested spores germinate in the midgut and invade the 
epithelial cells
•
Once in the cell, 
the fungus 
grows by absorbing nutrients from 
the cell
•
Cells damaged, affects digestion, causes malnutrition and 
premature death
•
Life spans of worker bees may be reduced up to 78%
•
Young workers infected by 
Nosema 
are not able to produce 
royal jelly 
-
 
can affect brood production and colony build
-
up

N
.
 
cerana
e
:  
Symptoms and Treatment
•
Heavy infection may lead to dysentery
•
Control
✓
E
limination of 
other 
stress
es
✓
U
se of antibiotic fumagillin (Fum
a
gil
l
in
-
B) which is fed in the fall as a 
preventative
 
(not super useful)
✓
Need of new methods!

Strong Hives 
Usually
 
are
 
h
ealthy 
h
ives
•
Most diseases can be avoided by keeping hives strong
•
Frequent examinations
 
catch issues early
•
Prevention
✓
Reduce colony stress, good hive locations with full sun
✓
Replace older combs which have a high probability of having 
spores
✓
Be
 
very
 
careful of switching combs between colonies
•
Good colony nutrition may help reduce problems 
-
 
pollen 
supplements in late winter and early spring can help promote 
colony health
•
Stresses (both disease and non
-
disease) often 
compound
 
upon 
each other, weakening colonies

Part 5. Microscopic pests in honey bees 
can be transmitted to wild bees

Pathogens/Parasites of honey bees are shared with other bee 
species on flowers (
Note: 
whether those bee species are negatively 
affected the way honey bees is u
nclear at the moment
)
Pathogen spillover occurs on flowers

Plant
-
pollinator visitation network
Graystock
 
et al., 2020 (https://
rdcu.be
/
dpXfQ
)
What happens if honey bees get sick?

Pathogen spillover to the whole community
Flower species 
with honey bee 
pathogens
Wild bee species 
with honey bee 
pathogens
Graystock
 
et al., 2020 (https://
rdcu.be
/
dpXfQ
)

Pathogen spillover to the whole community
Flower species 
with 
honey bee
 
pathogens
Wild bee species 
with 
honey bee
 
pathogens
•
63% flowers visited by 
honey bees
 
have “
honey 
bee
” pathogens on them
•
78% wild bees that visit 
those same flowers have 
“
honey bee
” pathogens

The teaching team is available 
for questions NOW and for ~ 10 minutes after class.
Do you wonder about anything? Come to talk to us!
•
The 
post
-
lecture 19 quiz 
is available and 
due on Friday at 12:20 PM
•
Weekly Sections for 
3
-
cr students 
will meet 
in their regular classroom. There is no 
homework prior to section
